content.description: Crimps and edges on a slightly less-than vertical wall.  Do a lip traverse left at the end to join the Slow Spring anchors. New titanium glue-in bolts.
content.location: Second route in the corridor on the right face.

content.description:
This is a new, direct start to Holladay-Ludwig (5.6) following the arete most of the way, climbing left of the bolts. The last 20' links into the Holladay-Ludwig, put up by Matthias Holladay and Richard Ludwig. I did not rebolt Holladay-Ludwig in its entirety because of sections of loose rock.

The crux was going direct at the fourth bolt with friction slab feet. I recently pulled off the big block with a crowbar and unfortunately it made going far right possible only about 5.6. Test yourself going direct, but you can always bail out right towards Holliday-Ludwig.

A new 5th bolt protects the follower from a nasty swing. It’s super super comfy to skip it on lead, but it is there to protect your follower. Clip it with a sling or long draw.

Oh yeah, and you'll have to follow the climb to clean it! Back clean the last bolt for your follower.

More crimps and edges on a slightly less-than-vertical face.  Crux is near the 3rd bolt making a couple long moves to reach and pull past a pocket.  At the last bolt head right, then back left on a wild lip traverse to the anchors.  New titanium glue-in bolts.
content.location: Third route in the corridor on the right wall.

content.description: Start in a right-facing corner/seam.  At the bulge, head right to the arete.  Nice moderate that would get more stars, except for a big ledge in the middle.  Cruiser climbing after the ledge.
content.location: To the right of the Clicking Barnacles arete, and just before you enter the corridor.

climbs.name: Pile Driver
climbs.fa: Bolted: Evan Wisheropp, FFA: Ethan Pringle 6/20

content.description:
NorCal's new hardest sport line? Right next to one of the world's hardest cracks? This route is a destination line for anyone climbing mid 5.14.

Three days of bolting, cleaning, and $250 of titanium revealed this climb to be much, much harder than I had bargained for and out of my league for more than one or two moves at a time (on a very good day). I bolted it solo using cam placements, multiple crazy directional ropes, and only one removable bolt. Yet there are no extra holes drilled on the route.

This unbelievable climb forks right from the fourth bolt of Doggy Style (5.13), hits a kneebar rest, and diagonals up and right following an insanely overhung line of pockets and underclings for a total of 11 bolts. The movement is absolutely top notch and insanely unique. The wall is STEEEEEP and relentless, with an incredible pump near the top. Ethan Pringle came in and put some real hard work in on the line and made it happen.
content.location: First four bolts of Doggystyle, then cut right.

climbs.name: Mutiny
climbs.fa: Nic Sabo, Austin Schuler, Matt Delheimer, 03/15

content.description: Bouldery crux start with a throw to a shallow dish.  Slap the arete then follow the pocketed prow to a second crux above the 4th bolt, pulling past a razor crimp.  Gets ocean spray at high tides, especially in the winter.
content.location: On the ocean-facing portion of the Puff Boulder.  Head past the Main Wall, drop over the little saddle, and scramble left along the base of the wall.  Starts off a large boulder.

content.description: Follow easy ledges up L then back R to top, gets good sun, runout-bolted on lead.

Somewhat short but severely overhung wall right next to the ocean.  This is an old Eric Chemello r.b. route that recently received titanium glue-in bolts.

This route was originally dubbed "Doggy Style" by Eric Chemello, but it's unclear if he ever red pointed it. Austin Schuler nabbed either the first or second ascent, and suggested naming it "Baby Herc".
content.location: On the west face of the Puff Boulder.  Easiest to walk past the Main Wall and scramble around to the left to approach.

content.description: Sharp arete. Stem for an easier start. Traverse L at top.
content.location: 1st route on the boulder. On the right when entering the gash.

content.description: Excellent warm up or first outdoor lead.  Less-than-vertical jug hauling.  Bottom might be damp at high tide, gets some ocean spray.
content.location: Left side of the south face of the Puff Boulder, just right of Holladay-Ludwig.
